thread.title: Orlando City still negotiating naming rights deal - Orlando Sentinel
thread.title_full: Orlando City still negotiating naming rights deal - Orlando Sentinel

author: orlandosentinel.com
title: Orlando City still negotiating naming rights deal - Orlando Sentinel
text:
Everything seemed to be coming together right after Jan. 1.
Orlando City was on track with construction of its $155 million, 25,500-seat stadium downtown and CEO Alex Leitão was optimistic about negotiations for the naming rights.
“I’m pretty confident that we are very close,” Leitão told the Orlando Sentinel on Jan. 2, adding the club was in advanced talks with one potential partner. “Could be this week.”
But the announcement never came. 
Orlando City Stadium has been the name on all press releases and renderings and it’s possible that name will stand when the season opens there March 5. 
Rob Parker, Orlando City’s vice president of corporate partnerships, said previous negotiations fell apart and discussions are now ongoing with multiple potential partners.
“At the time, we were heading into contracts with two potential parties,” Parker said. “Sometimes in deals like this things happen at the end, but we continue to be in good discussions and like the direction we’re heading with some of these brands.
“Deals don’t happen every day. I can’t share the reasons why some of those didn’t come to fruition. It’s not an issue with the club, with the value or anything like that. It’s just, sometimes these things don’t happen for one reason or another. No hard feelings. You move on ’til you get the right partner.”
Caption Orlando City unveils new home jerseys Orlando City unveiled new home jerseys, adopting a new look for its first season playing in a new stadium.
Orlando City unveiled new home jerseys, adopting a new look for its first season playing in a new stadium.

Caption Jason Kreis pleased with Orlando City's scrimmage vs Philadelphia Orlando City coach Jason Kreis said he saw some progress during the team's preseason scrimmage against the Philadelphia Union, which the Lions won 3-2.

Caption Orlando City goalkeeper coach Tim Mulqueen adjusting well to new job Orlando City goalkeeper coach Tim Mulqueen, who was hired in January to replace Stewart Kerr, says he is enjoying his new job and fits in well with the rest of the coaching staff.

Caption Brek Shea ready and eager to prove himself with Orlando City in 2017 Orlando City midfielder Brek Shea says he feels better than he has in a long time a team the start of the 2017 MLS season. He is ready to put last year's shortcomings behind him.
Orlando City midfielder Brek Shea says he feels better than he has in a long time a team the start of the 2017 MLS season. He is ready to put last year's shortcomings behind him.
Parker said he cannot reveal which organizations are in the mix due to non-disclosure agreements, but they include local, national and global companies. He did not have a timeline for when the naming rights may be finalized. 
“The timeline remains the same: whenever it’s right,” Parker said. “These are long-term partnerships, minimum 10-15 years. Could be done tomorrow, could be done in a few weeks. This is not something we’re going to rush into.
“We continue to be in discussion with people and on the phone every day with brands looking at us...value is there for right partner.”
The perfect partner for the club is a company that wants to invest in the community, has a vision for downtown Orlando, recognizes the growing soccer fan base and wants to support growth of the sport in the United States, according to Parker. 
The eventual partner’s name will grace five areas in the new stadium, based on master signage plans submitted to the city, including the upper left corner of a 1,935-square-foot image of the Lions’ logo painted on architectural metal panels.
"For us, it’s about finding the right strategic partner for the next 10-15 years,” he said. “And we’re willing to put the time and work into doing that.”
ardelgallo@orlandosentinel.com
